user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtSprintf:
```c
char *UtSprintf(const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list                     Args;
    static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];
    static uint32               TextIndex = 0;

    ++TextIndex;
    if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS)
        TextIndex = 0;

    va_start(Args, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf[TextIndex].Text, sizeof(Buf[TextIndex].Text), Spec, Args);
    va_end(Args);

    return Buf[TextIndex].Text;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtSprintf:
const char *Spec
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in the provided code. The only named parameter is 'Spec' (declared as const char *), and it is never assigned to, incremented, or otherwise changed. The uses of 'Spec' are: passed to va_start(Args, Spec) as the last named parameter (va_start does not modify the parameter itself), and passed to vsnprintf as the format string (a read-only use). The variadic arguments ('...') are not a named parameter and thus not subject to Rule 17.8 in the sense of modifying a named parameter. Other modifications in the function (incrementing the static TextIndex and writing into the static buffer Buf) do not affect any function parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
